Several people have solved the triangle, but I would like to comment on the “ASS triangle” which may have no, one, or two solutions. Thank you Robert Nichols for the handy drawing. By extending the line AC, you show the case of an obtuse angle, below line AB. The number of solutions depends on whether A is acute or obtuse and the relationship of a to c. On Robert’s drawing, drop an altitude from B to line AC, and, centered at B, draw two more circles with radii 8 and 10 cm. This serves to demonstrate the cases below: For acute A a <c*sinA, no solution, a is too short to reach the angle specified (sinC > 1) a = c*sinA, special case, one solution, C is 90° c*sinA < a < c, two solutions, C acute or obtuse a ≥ c, one solution, C is acute For obtuse A a ≤ c, no solution (sinC > 1) a > c, one solution, C is acute I bolded the PITA case, the others are pretty straightforward.

when we know two sides and the angle between them. To solve an SAS triangle. use The Law of Cosines to calculate the unknown side, then use The Law of Sines to find the smaller of the other two angles, and then use the three angles add to 180° to find the last angle.

This is an Angle-Side-Side set of circumstances, what my high school math teacher always called an “ASS triangle”. That means there is most likely two sets of angles and sides to complete the given information about a triangle.

No, it is not possible to solve this triangle. If you were given 2 sides and the angle between (SAS) you could use the Cosine Rule but an ASS triangle can be drawn two ways so there is not a unique solution.
